name: Kung Pao Tofu
description: This is not a complex recipes but there are many repeated ingredients. Read the instructions carefully and line up the ingredients before you start stir-frying.
recipeIngredient: 1 teaspoon Shaoxing rice wine or dry sherry
1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon Chinkiang vinegar, (or 1 tablespoon balsamic and 1 teaspoon cider vinegar)
1 teaspoon dark soy sauce, (or 1/2 teaspoon regular soy sauce plus 1/2 teaspoon molasses)
8  dried red chiles, (stemmed, halved lengthwise with scissors, seeds discarded)
White part of 4 large green onions, (cut to match size of peanuts)
Green part of 1 large green onion, (cut to match size of peanuts)

recipeInstructions.text: Cut the tofu into thumbnail-size cubes (each about 3/4 inch). Sprinkle on the salt and gently toss to coat. Spread out on 2 layers of paper towel and let drain for 10 to 15 minutes.
recipeInstructions.name: Cut the tofu into thumbnail-size cubes (each about 3/4 inch). Sprinkle on the salt and gently toss to coat. Spread out on 2 layers of paper towel and let drain for 10 to 15 minutes.

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 1 to 2 tablespoons of oil in a large wok or skillet over medium-high or high heat. When barely shimmering, add the tofu (work in batches, if needed), then cook for 1 to 2 minutes, tossing and stirring to sear and lightly brown the tofu. Transfer to bowl and set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Heat 1 to 2 tablespoons of oil in a large wok or skillet over medium-high or high heat. When barely shimmering, add the tofu (work in batches, if needed), then cook for 1 to 2 minutes, tossing and stirring to sear and lightly brown the tofu. Transfer to bowl and set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Reheat the wok or skillet over medium-high heat until bead of water evaporates in 2 to 3 seconds. Add 2 tablespoons of oil and the peanuts, stirring constantly for 1 to 2 minutes, until fragrant; take care not to burn them. Use a slotted spoon to transfer peanuts to small plate, leaving excess oil behind.
recipeInstructions.name: Reheat the wok or skillet over medium-high heat until bead of water evaporates in 2 to 3 seconds. Add 2 tablespoons of oil and the peanuts, stirring constantly for 1 to 2 minutes, until fragrant; take care not to burn them. Use a slotted spoon to transfer peanuts to small plate, leaving excess oil behind.

recipeInstructions.text: Stir together the ingredients for each of the seasoning sauces, keeping them separate. Set near the stove with the remaining ingredients from dried red chiles down to the green onion.
recipeInstructions.name: Stir together the ingredients for each of the seasoning sauces, keeping them separate. Set near the stove with the remaining ingredients from dried red chiles down to the green onion.

recipeInstructions.text: Reheat the wok or skillet over high heat. Add the chiles and Sichuan peppercorns. Stir briskly for 20 seconds, until aromatic and crisp. Add the tofu, give things a stir, then splash in seasoning sauce 1. Let the tofu absorb the seasonings, then add the garlic, ginger and white scallion parts. Stir-fry for 1 minute more to cook through and become aromatic.
recipeInstructions.name: Reheat the wok or skillet over high heat. Add the chiles and Sichuan peppercorns. Stir briskly for 20 seconds, until aromatic and crisp. Add the tofu, give things a stir, then splash in seasoning sauce 1. Let the tofu absorb the seasonings, then add the garlic, ginger and white scallion parts. Stir-fry for 1 minute more to cook through and become aromatic.

recipeInstructions.text: Give seasoning sauce 2 one last stir, then add to wok. When sauce is thick and coats things, about 30 seconds, return the peanuts and add cut green scallion parts. Stir, transfer to a plate, and serve.
recipeInstructions.name: Give seasoning sauce 2 one last stir, then add to wok. When sauce is thick and coats things, about 30 seconds, return the peanuts and add cut green scallion parts. Stir, transfer to a plate, and serve.

review.reviewBody: I feel so lucky to have found your recipe.  I made it tonight to great success.  Was so easy!  It’s going in my favorite recipe file.  This is the only Kung pao tofu recipe I’ll ever need or want!  Thanks again!!
